TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Loamy-skeletal, mixed, superactive, frigid Pachic Haplustolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Osha gravelly loam--woodland.  (Colors are for dry soils unless otherwise noted.)
Oi--3 inches to 0; undecomposed and partly decomposed leaves, needles, and twigs.
A1--0 to 11 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) gravelly loam, very dark brown (10YR 2/2) moist; fine granular structure in uppermost few inches; very weak, fine, subangular blocky structure in lower part; slightly hard, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; neutral; 30 percent fine pebbles; gradual smooth boundary.
A2--11 to 18 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) very gravelly loam, dark brown (10YR 3/3) moist; weak fine subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; neutral; 40 percent pebbles; gradual wavy boundary.
Bw--18 to 32 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) very gravelly coarse sandy loam, brown (10YR 5/3) moist; weak fine subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; 40 percent pebbles; gradual wavy boundary.
Bt--32 to 50 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) extremely gravelly sandy loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure; hard, friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; slightly acid; thin continuous clay films on faces of peds; about 80 percent pebbles; abrupt smooth boundary.
R--50 inches; hard, weakly fractured granite bedrock.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Torrance County, New Mexico; Cibola National Forest; SW 1/4 sec. 23, T. 7 N., R. 5 E.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:
Soil Moisture:  The soil moisture control section is moist in all parts during the 120 days following the winter solstice and is dry in all parts periodically during late May and June.  It is moist in all parts more than 40 percent of the time that the soil temperature is greater than 41 degrees F.
Soil Temperature:  44 to 47 degrees F.
Particle-size control section:  Fine-earth fraction by weighted average is finer than loamy fine sand and the clay content is 6 to 12 percent.
A horizon - Hue:  7.5YR or 10YR Value:  3 through 5 dry, 2 or 3 moist Chroma: 1 through 3 Texture:  Gravelly coarse sandy loam or very gravelly coarse sandy loam, gravelly loam, very gravelly loam
B or C horizon - Hue:  7.5YR or 10YR Value:  4 through 6 dry, 3 through 5 moist Chroma:  3 through 6 Texture:  coarse sandy loam or sandy loam Sand Content: more than 50 percent fine sand or coarser Rock Fragments:  35 to 80 percent pebbles by volume

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Bitton, Datino, Grousecreek (T), Heely (T), Labre, Perma, Pesmore, Peso, Pesowyo, Sandia, Slimbutte, Subwell, Veatch and Wanagin series.  The Bitton, Grousecreek, Perma, Slimbutte, and Wanagin soils are not dry in all parts of the soil moisture control section during the month of June.  The Datino, Labre, Pesmore, Peso, and Subwell soils have Bk or calcic horizons.  The Heely, Peso, Pesmore, Pesowyo, and Veatch soils are moderately deep.  The Sandia soils have particle-size control sections with 50 to 80 percent stones and cobbles and lack clay skins in the B or C horizons.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content:
GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Osha soils are on mountain ridges and sideslopes. They formed in material weathered from granite and support stands of ponderosa pine.
Elevation ranges from 6,500 to 9,000 feet.  Mean annual precipitation is 16 to 22 inches.  Mean annual temperature is 41 to 45 degrees F.  Frost-free period is 60 to 110 days.  Slopes range from 3 to 70 percent.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Laventana and Palon soils.  Both the Laventana and Palon soils lack a mollic epipedon.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; medium runoff; moderately rapid permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  This soil is used for timber production, wildlife habitat, livestock grazing, and recreation.  Present vegetation is ponderosa pine, Gambel oak, rock mountain juniper, mountain muhly, mountain brome, and muttongrass.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Northcentral and Central New Mexico.  Osha soils are of small extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Torrance County, New Mexico, 1968.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Classification change from:  Loamy-skeletal, mixed Typic Paleborolls to Loamy-skeletal, mixed Typic Haploborolls.  The soils lack sufficient clay increase to qualify as an argillic horizon.
DIAGNOSTIC HORIZONS AND FEATURES RECOGNIZED IN THIS PEDON ARE:
Mollic epipedon:  The zone from the surface to a depth of 11 inches. (A1 horizon)
Bt feature:  The zone from 32 to 50 inches, containing clay films but lacking sufficient clay increase to qualify as an argillic horizon.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
